function.name: execute_python
function.description: Execute Python code in a controlled environment and return the output, including stdout, stderr, and return values. The code execution is sandboxed using LangChain's PythonREPL.

code.description: Python code to execute. Can include multiple lines and statements.

input.code:
x = 5
y = 3
print(f'Sum: {x + y}')
x + y

examples.output:
Error executing code:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'this_module_does_not_exist'

function.name: save_sea_level_data
function.description: Fetch sea level data for a given location and save it as a CSV file in the '../data' directory. If a file for the same station exists and is less than 30 days old, the download is skipped.

location.description: Location name or station ID to fetch sea level data for

examples.output: Sea level data for station 9414290 saved to '../data/sea_level_9414290_timestamp.csv'
Sea level data for Los Angeles saved to '../data/sea_level_stationID_timestamp.csv'

function.name: analyze_sea_level_data
function.description: Analyze sea level data from the uploaded CSV file

operation.description: The operation to perform on the data

n.description: Number of rows to show for head or tail operations

examples.output: Showing the first 5 rows of the sea level data:
Showing the last 5 rows of the sea level data:
Descriptive statistics of the sea level data:

function.name: plot_sea_level_trend
function.description: Plot sea level trend from the uploaded CSV file

x_column.description: The column to use for the x-axis

y_column.description: The column to use for the y-axis

start_year.description: The start year for filtering the data (optional)

end_year.description: The end year for filtering the data (optional)

examples.output: Plotting sea level trend for the entire dataset
Plotting sea level trend from 2001 to 2006
